Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Design and modeling of novel superconducting circuits with coherent phase slips

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Superconductivity is a quantum phenomenon that manifests itself as an abrupt disappearance of resistivity in certain materials as temperature is lowered below their critical temperature. Recent advances in the nanometer size fabrication, materials science and high precision measurements made it possible to investigate a variety of novel superconducting nanosystems, which were almost unthinkable only a few years ago. Specifically the studies of quantum transport phenomena in nanoscale superconducting wires and circuits made of them are rapidly emerging as one of the central themes of modern physics and engineering. As wire is made narrower, a variety of intriguing quantum effects becomes apparent. Strong spatial confinement leads to intricate electron correlations that influence superconducting properties of the structure. Ultimately superconductivity could be gradually extinguished and some wires may display pronounced insulating behavior, leading to the so-called superconductor-insulator transition. Superconductors are extremely attractive systems from the point of view of future applications as they could become elementary building blocks for memory bits of quantum computers and other devices operating on coherent quantum tunneling events. The main aim of this joint project is to harness the power of quantum coherence, address the urgent problems of nanoscale-circuit-superconductivity at the frontier of current research, and discover new physics in this exciting field. Our approach will be to combine the expertise of a condensed matter theorist and an experimentalist both having extended experience in related fields. The collaborative structure of the research will provide a rich environment for training students in a broad spectrum of experimental nanoscience and theoretical condensed matter physics. Educational aspects will be further integrated through the development of courses directly related to the proposed research and through research-related seminars, science olympiads, and meetings that target high-school teachers.

The goal of the project is to study emergent quantum transport phenomena in the modern nanoscale superconducting circuits driven far from equilibrium and populated with coherent phase slips to reveal the ultimate fate of superconducting correlations in the new domain of external conditions and environments. A substantial part of the proposed research is devoted to stochastic kinetics of the coherent phase slips in superconducting nanowires, nanowire-bridged resonators, and interferometers. The focus in on the mutual role of microwave bias and a magnetic field on the reentrant superconductivity, statistics of the supercurrent switching, bi-stability and current-voltage characteristics, and a study of even-odd parity effects for the phase slip tunneling events. Suggested studies of the excess shot noise, carried across the superconducting transition, will provide additional insights into the microscopic mechanisms of the relaxation and fluctuations. The project also dwells into the new area of exploring proximity-induced superconductivity between superconducting and semiconducting heterostructures that host topological order. This research direction aims to answer the key questions concerning robustness and stability of the topological protection to effects of interactions, disorder and other relevant perturbations. The long-term goal of this project is to develop novel superconducting qubits with coherent phase slips for quantum circuit electrodynamics applications. The proposed architecture designs are based on the phase-slip-junction, the phase-slip-oscillator and an alternative device based on the supercurrent carrying inductor with tunable nonlinearity. The success and completion of this proposal will be of value for the technological advances in the information processing and the photon detection. The technical and theoretical methods that will be developed as a part of this proposal are relevant to a much wider class of problems in the quantum physics of many-body systems. The results of the proposed work will be widely disseminated in publications, seminars, colloquia and conference presentations. Students working under this project will receive extensive training by studying modern aspects of the condensed matter physics, developing new conceptual approaches to nonequilibrium superconducting systems and pursuing original research. As a part of the diversity and educational initiatives PIs will expand research opportunities for the undergraduate students of underrepresented groups and contribute to the science olympiad interscholastic competition program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Macroscopic quantum tunneling is a fundamental phenomenon of quantum mechanics related to a fundamental question about how and why a quantum system transforms into a classical Newtonian system as its dimensions increase. Qubits represent an exceptional situation in which a rather large system, of the scale of a few microns, behaves quantum mechanically, in analogy with a single electron for example. The ability to realize macroscopic quantum tunneling affects implementation of qubit-based quantum computing schemes and their protection against decoherence. Decoherence in qubits, i.e. the unintended loss of quantum information, can be reduced by means of so-called topological protection, e.g., by exploiting various parity effects. Paired phase slips can provide such protection for superconducting qubits.

One of our key results is the direct observation of quantum paired phase slips in nanoscale superconducting loops. We have been able to develop samples allowing us to detect single phase slips in superconducting loops. Due to this ability we could distinguish single phase slips and double phase slips. We show that in addition to conventional single phase slips that change the superconducting order parameter phase by 2π, there are quantum transitions that change the phase by 4π. It was discovered that double phase slips are exponentially more probable than the single ones in the cases when the bias current is zero.Quantum paired phase slips represent a synchronized occurrence of two macroscopic quantum tunneling events, which is a signature of quantum coherence between the phase slip events forming these pairs. We demonstrate the existence of a remarkable regime in which paired phase slips are exponentially more probable than single ones. This can be used to build new quantum circuits characterized by improved stability against decoherence. The results have been published in Physical Review X.

Another key result is that we were able to collect evidence that individual phase slips can be created at will. For this purpose, an asymmetric superconducting loop has been biased with appropriate currents and magnetic field. A quantum phase slips occurs if the temperature is sufficiently low and if the system is manipulated to an edge its stability diamond. We demonstrated that the achieved control over the phase slips can be used to make superconducting memory device. When the method of fabrication is electron beam lithography, then we could make superconducting memory cells with dimensions similar to 200 nm. This is a many times improvement in the dimension scale compared to previously demonstrated superconducting memory. Such significant reduction of the dimensions is due to the fact that the kinetic inductance of nanowires dwarfs their geometric inductance. This means that the nanowires can be very small and still possess a large kinetic inductance. We also developed a model describing the parameter field in which such phase slips can be achieved. It was understood that the key parameter controlling our devices is the critical phase of the nanowires, i.e., the value of the phase difference at which the wire reaches its departing critical current. It turns out that controlled single phase slips can be induced even at zero magnetic field, by means of current biasing, if the value of the critical phase is different for the wires from which the loop is composed. Such loops are naturally termed ?asymmetric loops?. The key outcome is the creation of a memory device with dimensions approaching 100 nm. Previously demonstrated superconducting memory cells were much larger, of the order of one micron. Our device operation is based on the kinetic inductance of the nanowire, rather than on the geometric inductance, as was done previously.

Broader Impact: Superconducting computers will enable transformative advances in our ability to process large amounts of information rapidly. Novel quantum phenomena, especially those related to quantum phase slips, will have a strong impact on technology and metrology. Our result move us closer to the point when quantum phase slips will find applications in practical systems. The results of the project have been widely disseminated in publications, seminars, colloquia, and conference presentations. Under this project, graduate and undergraduate students received extensive training in conducting original research in modern condensed matter physics, microwave technology, cryogenics, and nanotechnology. Young scientists have received training in professional standards for the responsible conduct of research. Such training have included mentoring and discussions of standards of collecting, analyzing, and preserving research data, proper referencing of scholarly work reported by other researchers, responsibilities of authors and co-authors and acceptable authorship practices, and timely publication and dissemination of research results. The PI have provided training for Illinois undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 10/30/2018
Modified by: Alexey Bezryadin

Image
  • Nanowires with diameters ~25 nm nm are used to build a superconducting memory element. The system is switched by means of phase slips and the information is encoded in the vorticity of the condensate on the superconducting loop.
    A. Murphy and A. Bezryadin
    Copyrighted
    Alexey Bezryadin
    Superconducting Memory Element with Dimensions of the order of 150 nm
